description: Works well, does it's job, doesn't get in the way. As advertised.
Used it for years. Simple but works fine.

One star deducted because it's painfully sloooooooooooow

First time starting it, it already knew the iso and where to put it. I hit start. Done. Great app!

It does exactly what it says it does. You can't really ask for more than that.

While creating a Ubuntu 18.04 LTS startup disk, the boot command shows 
Failed to load ldlinux.c32 
Don't use this one.
You can select an ISO file, but it disappears when attempting to create the disk.

I just literally installed this program for the first time and ran it. It immediately found the ISO I had just downloaded and my USB drive. It then quickly installed it on the USB drive and I was able to boot to it.
Recognises .iso and usb immediately. Efficient little app.
To solve the problem of not finding ISOs, change the extension from ".iso" to ".img" and it will find it. Works otherwise, but had to spend time looking for a solution
summary: Didn't find ISOs, works otherwise (Solution Below)

description: Easy and straightforward to use.
Cant seem to recognize the ISO on ubuntu 19.04
Will not add an .iso file. Will not recognize usb unless it is mounted. When mounted, software will not do anything with the usb. Back to the old dd command.

It's stable. It's fast... but.. it lacks configuration and options of any type. There are two inputs to the software: Your destination drive, and your Source ISO. That's it. Press the button and it exits on completion. 

It can't be just any ISO, it has to contain a Linux Distro on it. I've only tested debian-based distros... They all work great. Any other ISO (including "SystemRescueCD") won't even populate the file widget to select your source.

There is NO "persistence" option either. And the ISO is resized to take up the entire device, not just a partition. At the end of the operation... you have the ISO on your USB drive, and ONLY your ISO on your drive. Regardless of capacity.

I have been able to add persistence manually through parted by determining what % of the drive was free, and using "parted"; mkfs, and e2label from the CLI. 

So if you're burning Ubuntu, Mint, Kali, Parrot, and the like, this program is perfect.

If you need any flexibility, you'll probably be adding 3rd party ppa's or... like I did... fumble for hours on prerequisites to compile some source code written for an outdated version of your OS.

TL;DR
Doesn't do much, but great at what it does.

 4 of 5 stars.

description: This is the best tool out there in Ubuntu World. Cheers Devs!

As written in the description, this only works for Debian-based distros.

This little app is great! There's not a lot to be said beyond that, but I'll go into detail on this elegant, simple, and well-designed app anyways.

In the ideal circumstance (ISOs in a known location, and only one removable drive present) it's two clicks -- one to start the write, then 'ok' at the end.

If multiple images are present, select the one you want to use. If the app doesn't find the image you want, no sweat -- click 'other' and select your file from the file chooser.

This app (wisely) only includes removable drives (USB, SDHC, etc) in the list of targets, and automatically updates the list if you insert a drive after the app is already started.

This is a small detail, and I'm unsure whether it's a new Ubuntu feature or an update to this app. But the latest version thankfully won't cache the write. Some older imagers will fill the 600mb write-behind cache (bumping the progress bar to, say, 25%) when writing has only just started. Then, when the bar is 100% full, you still have to wait for it to catch up with writing the last 25%.
But not anymore! Progress bar follows the actual progress, and finishes right when it says it will.

Simple, and a pleasure to use.
summary: Great app, simple, well-designed, and fast

description: I have no idea what people are talking about that are saying it won't find their ISO files regardless of where they put them. You can browse to wherever you want. You don't have to put them any particular place. Just browse to wherever you put them.

源文件打不开,没办法下载的balena-etcher：
Debian and Ubuntu based Package Repository (GNU/Linux x86/x64)
  1. Add Etcher debian repository:
    echo "deb https://deb.etcher.io stable etcher" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/balena-etcher.list
  2. Trust Bintray.com's GPG key:
    sudo apt-key adv --keyserver hkps://keyserver.ubuntu.com:443 --recv-keys 379CE192D401AB61
  3. Update and install:
     sudo apt-get update
     sudo apt-get install balena-etcher-electron
#Uninstall
sudo apt-get remove balena-etcher-electron
sudo rm /etc/apt/sources.list.d/balena-etcher.list
sudo apt-get update
